body_html:
@waleedka You should use .export() method which saves (meta)graph + checkpoints. It enables to load using TensorFlow Servo model back and serve at scale. If you want to restore and use in Python - right now you need to have code around. We are working on making that to work reliably from exported graph, but it still a bit down the line.

@snbuchholz You probably should use .export() on your Estimator to save into some temporary directory. Then write custom "copier" that would upload (meta)graph and checkpoints into database.

@waleedka You should use .export() method which saves (meta)graph + checkpoints. It enables to load using TensorFlow Servo model back and serve at scale. If you want to restore and use in Python - right now you need to have code around. We are working on making that to work reliably from exported graph, but it still a bit down the line.
@snbuchholz You probably should use .export() on your Estimator to save into some temporary directory. Then write custom "copier" that would upload (meta)graph and checkpoints into database.
body:
@waleedka You should use `.export()` method which saves (meta)graph + checkpoints. It enables to load using TensorFlow Servo model back and serve at scale. If you want to restore and use in Python - right now you need to have code around. We are working on making that to work reliably from exported graph, but it still a bit down the line.

@snbuchholz You probably should use `.export()` on your Estimator to save into some temporary directory. Then write custom "copier" that would upload (meta)graph and checkpoints into database.
